t: Isaiah 14
Israel’s Taunt
When*p the Lord*s will have compassion on Jacob and again choose Israel, and settle them in their own land, then strangers will join them and attach themselves to the house of Jacob.

The peoples will take them along and bring them to their place, and the house of Israel will possess them as an inheritance in the land of the Lord*s as male servants and female servants; and they will take their captors captive and will rule over their oppressors.
And*p it will be in the day when the Lord*s gives you rest from your pain and turmoil and harsh service in which you have been enslaved,
that you will take up this taunt against the king of Babylon, and say, “How*pn the oppressor has ceased, And*iln how*i fury has ceased!
The*ln Lord*s has broken the staff of the wicked, The*ln scepter of rulers
Which*ln used to strike the peoples in fury with unceasing strokes, Which*ln subdued the nations in anger with unrestrained persecution.
The*ln whole earth is at rest and*i is quiet; They*ln break forth into shouts of joy.
Even*ln the cypress trees rejoice over you, and*i the cedars of Lebanon, saying,*i ‘Since*ln you were laid low, no tree*i cutter comes up against us.’

Sheol*ln from beneath is excited over you to meet you when you come; It*ln arouses for you the spirits of the dead, all the leaders of the earth; It*ln raises all the kings of the nations from their thrones.
They*ln will all respond and say to you, ‘Even*ln you have been made weak as we, You*ln have become like us.
Your*ln pomp and*i the music of your harps Have*ln been brought down to Sheol; Maggots*ln are spread out as*i your*i bed*i beneath you And*ln worms are your covering.’
How*ln you have fallen from heaven, O*ln star of the morning, son of the dawn! You*ln have been cut down to the earth, You*ln who have weakened the nations!
But*ln you said in your heart, ‘I*ln will ascend to heaven; I*ln will raise my throne above the stars of God, And*ln I will sit on the mount of assembly In*ln the recesses of the north.
I*ln will ascend above the heights of the clouds; I*ln will make myself like the Most High.’
Nevertheless*ln you will be thrust down to Sheol, To*ln the recesses of the pit.
Those*ln who see you will gaze at you, They*ln will ponder over you, saying,*i ‘Is*ln this the man who made the earth tremble, Who*ln shook kingdoms,
Who*ln made the world like a wilderness And*ln overthrew its cities, Who*ln did not allow his prisoners to go*i home?’
All*ln the kings of the nations lie in glory, Each*ln in his own tomb.
But*ln you have been cast out of your tomb Like*ln a rejected branch, Clothed*ln with the slain who are pierced with a sword, Who*ln go down to the stones of the pit Like*ln a trampled corpse.
You*ln will not be united with them in burial, Because*ln you have ruined your country, You*ln have slain your people. May*ln the offspring of evildoers not be mentioned forever.
Prepare*ln for his sons a place of slaughter Because*ln of the iniquity of their fathers. They*ln must not arise and take possession of the earth And*ln fill the face of the world with cities.”
“I*p will rise up against them,” declares the Lord*s of hosts, “and will cut off from Babylon name and survivors, offspring and posterity,” declares the Lord.*s
“I will also make it a possession for the hedgehog and swamps of water, and I will sweep it with the broom of destruction,” declares the Lord*s of hosts.
Judgment on Assyria
The*p Lord*s of hosts has sworn saying, “Surely, just as I have intended so it has happened, and just as I have planned so it will stand,
to break Assyria in My land, and I will trample him on My mountains. Then his yoke will be removed from them and his burden removed from their shoulder.
This is the plan devised against the whole earth; and this is the hand that is stretched out against all the nations.
For the Lord*s of hosts has planned, and who can frustrate it?*i And as for His stretched-out hand, who can turn it back?”
In*p the year that King Ahaz died this oracle came:
Judgment on Philistia
“Do*pn not rejoice, O Philistia, all of you, Because*ln the rod that struck you is broken; For*ln from the serpent’s root a viper will come out, And*ln its fruit will be a flying serpent.
Those*ln who are most helpless will eat, And*ln the needy will lie down in security; I*ln will destroy your root with famine, And*ln it will kill off your survivors.
Wail,*ln O gate; cry, O city; Melt*ln away, O Philistia, all of you; For*ln smoke comes from the north, And*ln there is no straggler in his ranks.
How*ln then will one answer the messengers of the nation? That*ln the Lord*s has founded Zion, And*ln the afflicted of His people will seek refuge in it.”
